docs.lead_paragraph: Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, a moderate Democrat known for his ability to cut political deals, was chosen today to be chairman of a commission that will suggest ways to redesign Medicare to guarantee health insurance for aging baby boomers. Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California, will have a major role in the commission's work under a complex power-sharing arrangement negotiated by President Clinton, Mr. Breaux and Congressional Republicans.

headline.main: Deal-Brokering Democrat Will Lead a Panel on Medicare

docs.abstract: Louisiana Sen John Breaux, moderate Democrat known for ability to cut political deals, will head commission that will suggest ways to redesign Medicare so as to assure benefits for aging baby boomers; Republican Repr Bill Thomas of California will also play major role under complex power-sharing arrangement negotiated by Pres Clinton, Breaux and Congressional Republicans; Breaux and Thomas will jointly supervise 17-member panel (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-5 Turkey's Largest Party Is Banned by High Court Turkey's highest court placed an immediate ban on the country's largest political party, finding it had a subversive agenda and was working to replace the nation's secular order with a rule based on Islam. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The decision by Aetna Inc. and its U.S. Healthcare plans to reverse the policy of providing comprehensive fertility care (front page, Jan. 10) marks a sad day for infertile couples. The U.S. Healthcare policy recognized infertility as a disease and allowed access to the most current treatment but also controlled costs. By U.S. Healthcare's accounting, only 0.3 percent used advanced reproductive techniques like in vitro fertilization.
docs.abstract: Letter by Drs Richard V Grazi, Susan M Lobel and Daniel E Stein criticizes decision by Aetna and US Healthcare to stop covering infertility treatments; says real problem is that treatments are costly when competitors get free ride (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The decision by Aetna Inc. and its U.S. Healthcare plans to reverse the policy of providing comprehensive fertility care (front page, Jan. 10) marks a sad day for infertile couples. The U.S. Healthcare policy recognized infertility...

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yesterday signed into law a bill that sharply increases the penalties for health insurance fraud and allows courts to permanently revoke the licenses of doctors who are involved in insurance fraud cases. Under the law, prosecutors can now seek penalties of up to 10 years in prison and fines of up to $150,000 for health care practitioners who commit deliberate fraud involving as little as $1,000. Previously, prosecutors had to prove that fraudulent claims totaled $75,000 or more in order to seek such stringent penalties.

headline.main: New Law Cracks Down On Health-Fraud Doctors

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna U.S. Healthcare said yesterday that it would charge extra for coverage for in vitro fertilization and other advanced reproductive treatments in places where Aetna had included the procedure as part of its basic coverage. U.S. Healthcare, a subsidiary of Aetna Inc., is a pioneer in reproductive coverage; it began offering in vitro fertilization in 1995.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Aetna to Charge Extra For In Vitro Fertilization

docs.abstract: Aetna US Healthcare says it will charge extra for coverage for in vitro fertilization and other advanced reproductive treatments in places where Aetna had included procedure as part of its basic coverage (S)
